text.text: Welcome to the WidgetKit Digital Lounge!

blocks.alt_text: A multi-colored gear on a black background

text.text: Welcome to the WWDC22 WidgetKit Digital Lounge! We’ve got an exciting week planned for you. You can find the full schedule of events in the <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=agrl496m| Apple Developer app and on developer.apple.com>, and activities for all lounges kick off on June 7.
If you haven't already, please take a moment to familiarize yourself with <https://developer.apple.com/news/?id=735utu4s|how the Digital Lounges will work>.

We want to make sure these spaces are helpful and welcoming for everyone — developers and Apple employees alike. Please review and follow the <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/policies/interactive-events/1/Apple-Developer-WWDC22-Interactive-Events-Attendance-Policy.pdf| WWDC22 Interactive Events Policy>.

messages.text:
Hello all! Welcome to the Complications and widgets: Reloaded Watch Party! We’re excited to have you all here! I'm Michael and I manage the watchOS Complications team. In this hour, we'll all watch Complications and widgets: Reloaded together! Get the video ready and be prepared to hit play at 12:05 PDT.

In the meantime, I’m so excited to introduce you to the speakers, <@U03HHJ4LRU2> and <@U03HKV0T82Y>. In addition to Devon and Graham, we've got many other members of the WidgetKit and Complications teams here to answer your questions!

There’s a lot of us here, so we'll to do our best to keep things organized. As the video progresses, I’ll be creating threads associated with each section of the talk, where everyone can chat and ask questions.

When the video finishes, we’ll have some time left over for additional targeted Q&A, which I’ll explain when we get there. So for the next few minutes, grab your popcorn, get comfortable, and get ready to hit that play button!

messages.text:
<@U03JRR4R3CY> asked
> How to deal with relative dates in the widget, such as counting down the end of a match, does the relative style update the time every second?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How to deal with relative dates in the widget, such as counting down the end of a match, does the relative style update the time every second?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The system will update your relative date text every second, or with whatever fidelity is needed for the current style

elements.text: The system will update your relative date text every second, or with whatever fidelity is needed for the current style

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That way, you can get secondly updates with only a single timeline entry

elements.text: That way, you can get secondly updates with only a single timeline entry

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Great, thanks :slightly_smiling_face:
So the lock screen widgets can get updates every second if needed?

elements.text: So the lock screen widgets can get updates every second if needed?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Relative time will update every second if it’s showing seconds, without needing the widget itself to update.

elements.text: Relative time will update every second if it’s showing seconds, without needing the widget itself to update.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks!
Same updating applies to the new ProgressView option.

<@U03HMBY0SDV> asked
> I noticed that users can choose in Settings whether they want widgets to be redacted when the device is locked, similarly to notifications. I looked in my iPhone’s Settings and couldn’t find this option (I guess I just missed it); where is it?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"I noticed that users can choose in Settings whether they want widgets to be redacted when the device is locked, similarly to notifications. messages.text:
<@U03JELPN197> asked
> Has the update policy for Complications/Widgets changed or is it still a minimum of 15 minutes?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Has the update policy for Complications\/Widgets changed or is it still a minimum of 15 minutes?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It has not changed for WidgetKit but is slightly different from ClockKit (for Complications). ~15 minutes is about right but please see this article for more details <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/widgetkit/keeping-a-widget-up-to-date>

elements.text: It has not changed for WidgetKit but is slightly different from ClockKit (for Complications). ~15 minutes is about right but please see this article for more details

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Ideally you wouldn’t want to update your widget all that frequently

elements.text: Ideally you wouldn’t want to update your widget all that frequently

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can provide timeline entries at a higher frequency than 15 minutes, but there is a quota on timeline reloads.

elements.text: You can provide timeline entries at a higher frequency than 15 minutes, but there is a quota on timeline reloads.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks :raised_hands:.

elements.text: Great question! You can implement a custom TimelineProvider to control this. You can find more details under “Generate a Timeline for Predictable Events” in this article.

messages.text:
<@U03JELPN197> asked
> Is it somehow possible to sync data from an Intent on the iPhone to a Complication on the Watch "on the fly"? If I would add something with an Intent, a new Donut for example, on my Phone, could you then somehow trigger an update of a Counter Complication on the Watch?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is it somehow possible to sync data from an Intent on the iPhone to a Complication on the Watch \"on the fly\"? If I would add something with an Intent, a new Donut for example, on my Phone, could you then somehow trigger an update of a Counter Complication on the Watch?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Are you saying you’d like to sync user selections of intents between phone & watch?

elements.text: Are you saying you’d like to sync user selections of intents between phone & watch?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s not possible, but seems like a good idea! Please file some feedback!

elements.text: That’s not possible, but seems like a good idea! Please file some feedback!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The user of our app are using Phone and Watch a lot, and we have Complications / Widgets for Calories, Activities, Steps and more. Sometimes they track Activities on the Watch, sometimes they add Food on the Phone. The user expects that if the add something on one device that the Widgets / Complications update instantly on their other device.

elements.text: The user of our app are using Phone and Watch a lot, and we have Complications / Widgets for Calories, Activities, Steps and more. Sometimes they track Activities on the Watch, sometimes they add Food on the Phone. The user expects that if the add something on one device that the Widgets / Complications update instantly on their other device.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: And ofc we already have Siri Intents to add Foods for example

elements.text: And ofc we already have Siri Intents to add Foods for example

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can use WatchConnectivity or other data sync frameworks to ensure that both devices are able to communicate their inputs. Your watchOS and iOS apps can both request the widget to get reloaded after the data syncs between the two

elements.text: You can use WatchConnectivity or other data sync frameworks to ensure that both devices are able to communicate their inputs. Your watchOS and iOS apps can both request the widget to get reloaded after the data syncs between the two

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The WidgetKit framework doesn't provide any utilities to help sync data or entries, though. That'll need to happen as part of your app.

elements.text: The WidgetKit framework doesn't provide any utilities to help sync data or entries, though. That'll need to happen as part of your app.

messages.text:
<@U03JXKJUN2U> asked
> How does a user decide when they want the content on a widget to be redacted? Can this be configured per widget?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"How does a user decide when they want the content on a widget to be redacted? Can this be configured per widget?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Users can specify that they want all widgets redacted or not on iOS under Settings -> Face ID & Passcode. Complications can be individually configured on watchOS under Settings -> Display & Brightness -> Always On

elements.text: Users can specify that they want all widgets redacted or not on iOS under Settings -> Face ID & Passcode. Complications can be individually configured on watchOS under Settings -> Display & Brightness -> Always On

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Applications can also specify settings for your app and then set redaction in code, on or off. This would allow you to provide your users with fine grain control if required.

elements.text: Applications can also specify settings for your app and then set redaction in code, on or off. This would allow you to provide your users with fine grain control if required.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: see `.privacySensitive`, we mentioned it near the end of the talk

elements.text: , we mentioned it near the end of the talk

messages.text:
<@U03JELPN197> asked
> Is there a time limit for networking and processing when reloading Widgets / Complications?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is there a time limit for networking and processing when reloading Widgets \/ Complications?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, there are limits. You can use background download tasks to save runtime. The system will carry out your network request and wake your extension again once it's completed.

elements.text: Yes, there are limits. You can use background download tasks to save runtime. The system will carry out your network request and wake your extension again once it's completed.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: There's more details on <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/widgetkit/keeping-a-widget-up-to-date>
There is a finite time limit for your extension to give back a timeline, too

elements.text: There is a finite time limit for your extension to give back a timeline, too

Hey all! I hope you’ve had a great WWDC so far and that you’ve had a blast exploring our updates to WidgetKit! We’ll be getting our first Q&A session started in 5 minutes.

Once we get started, you can click the lightning bolt :shortcut: and use “Ask a question” to submit anything you’re curious about about WidgetKit and Complications!

elements.text:
Hey all! I hope you’ve had a great WWDC so far and that you’ve had a blast exploring our updates to WidgetKit! We’ll be getting our first Q&A session started in 5 minutes.

Once we get started, you can click the lightning bolt
and use “Ask a question” to submit anything you’re curious about about WidgetKit and Complications!

messages.text: <@U03HHJ4LRU2> added a workflow to this channel: *WidgetKit - Ask a Question*.

<@U03JPJ277SQ> asked
> Hello. Is there any way we could create an analog clock complication/widget using ClockKit/WidgetKit? Does the system allow us to ask for updates every minute?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Hello. Is there any way we could create an analog clock complication\/widget using ClockKit\/WidgetKit? Does the system allow us to ask for updates every minute?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can create a widget with minute and hour hands in WidgetKit for sure! You'll want to specify a once a minute timeline when your extension is asked for a timeline to make sure your time stays up to date

elements.text: You can create a widget with minute and hour hands in WidgetKit for sure! You'll want to specify a once a minute timeline when your extension is asked for a timeline to make sure your time stays up to date

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
There’s something I’m still not clear about. You’re saying that I can provide a timeline with data at every minute?
How’s this not hitting the system update budget? I saw you answered something about this in some other question. <@U03HHJ4LRU2>

elements.text:
There’s something I’m still not clear about. You’re saying that I can provide a timeline with data at every minute?
How’s this not hitting the system update budget? I saw you answered something about this in some other question.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The budgeting cares much more about the runtime your extension gets (and therefore the amount of times you reload your timeline), not the number of entries you provide. Something like a clock is _highly_ predictable, so you can provide many entries in a single wake of your extension.

elements.text: The budgeting cares much more about the runtime your extension gets (and therefore the amount of times you reload your timeline), not the number of entries you provide. Something like a clock is
predictable, so you can provide many entries in a single wake of your extension.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: That’s great. Thanks.

Is there a limit to how many entries we should put in a timeline or a limit on how much processor time we have to return a timeline? In the past, I've tried to return a timeline with per-minute updates but any more than around 100 entries/minutes will fail.

messages.text:
<@U03JPJ277SQ> asked
> Thanks for your previous answer. What options do we have at our disposal to make our widgets look more live? I’ve already been using `.timer` in `Text` . Is it possible to use such feature in any other form? Is using TimelineView allowed in WidgetKit? What is the rate limit of updating widgets using the timeline? How many items could we provide in the widget/complication timeline?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Thanks for your previous answer. What options do we have at our disposal to make our widgets look more live? I\u2019ve already been using `.timer` in `Text` . Is it possible to use such feature in any other form? Is using TimelineView allowed in WidgetKit? slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi Jim, my recommendation is to follow best practices around unit testing and target the logic specific to your widget. Since rendering, etc… is up to the system and it’s a bit difficult to UI test I would recommend focusing on UTs.

I would recommend reaching out to <https://developer.apple.com/wwdc22/topics/swiftui-ui-frameworks/#current|SwiftUI> to see if they have any recommendations if you want to dig more into UI testing.

<@U03K2PYH95E> asked
> Is there some way for a widget extension to ask for data from the host application?
> 
> We have an api client in our normal iOS app which has accessToken logic. So it knows if it is authenticated and it can refresh the token.
> 
> Now I want my widget extension to be able to also fetch new data when it gets reloaded.
> What is the common approach here?
> 
> Do I need a separate api client for the widget extension with its own separate token? Or do you recommend to use the same token and share it.
> 
> Or can the widget request data from the iOS app directly?
> 
> Thanks

elements.Raw:
{"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is there some way for a widget extension to ask for data from the host application?

We have an api client in our normal iOS app which has accessToken logic. So it knows if it is authenticated and it can refresh the token.

Now I want my widget extension to be able to also fetch new data when it gets reloaded.
What is the common approach here?

Do I need a separate api client for the widget extension with its own separate token? Or do you recommend to use the same token and share it.

Or can the widget request data from the iOS app directly?

Thanks"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
That’s a great question!
Typically the extension doesn’t request data from the app. Instead, the app would know there’s new data, and tell WidgetCenter to reload the widgets. The app could have saved data to the file system (shared app container) for the extension to read from & display

elements.text:

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
It sounds reasonable to alternatively have the app save out the access token and then have the extension do the networking.
Just be sure that the extension can respond to getTimeline() in a reasonable timeframe (seconds)

Okay thanks. I was just interested if there was something similar to WCSession for WidgetKit.

Our use case is that we show the status of your car in the widget. Like if it is locked and the current range etc.
And we want this data to be up to date when the user looks at the widget. And the user might not open the iOS app for some time.

So then I guess we have 2 options.
Either make a push notification to iOS app when the state changes and have it update the shared data for the widget.

Or have the widget update itself regularly and then build some api client into it.

Or would you advise against this? The reason for that is to make sure that the code is called at least once before a TimelineProvider life cycle method. The alternative would be to call this code in all three life cycle methods."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This is technically safe to do, but your TimelineProviders may be created and not queried - if they system is querying what widgets you have available, for example, we'll create all your widget configurations, which then create your TimelineProviders. We may not be fetching your widget timelines then, so you'd be fetching your data and spending some of your runtime budget unnecessarily.

elements.text: This is technically safe to do, but your TimelineProviders may be created and not queried - if they system is querying what widgets you have available, for example, we'll create all your widget configurations, which then create your TimelineProviders. We may not be fetching your widget timelines then, so you'd be fetching your data and spending some of your runtime budget unnecessarily.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I'd recommend waiting until the timeline fetching methods are called to load the needed data. You can certainly cache it to avoid redundant loads between requests, though!

elements.text: I'd recommend waiting until the timeline fetching methods are called to load the needed data. You can certainly cache it to avoid redundant loads between requests, though!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The background of the question is not about data loading but about accessing CoreData. Before  reading/writing to it we need checked if a migration is necessary and if it is, then perform it.

elements.text: The background of the question is not about data loading but about accessing CoreData. Before  reading/writing to it we need checked if a migration is necessary and if it is, then perform it.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: So would you recommend to better check (and migrate if necessary) explicitly in the getSnapshot and getTimeline method?

elements.text: So would you recommend to better check (and migrate if necessary) explicitly in the getSnapshot and getTimeline method?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Or am I overthinking this? Would it be sufficient to only check for the migration in the getSnapshot method, if it is always called before the getTimeline method?

elements.text: Or am I overthinking this? Would it be sufficient to only check for the migration in the getSnapshot method, if it is always called before the getTimeline method?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I don’t see why init isn’t a totally reasonable place to do that.

elements.text: I don’t see why init isn’t a totally reasonable place to do that.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Maybe it could become an issue if in future releases the TimelineProvider implementation and system usage is changed? So when it is not the default *init*() anymore but with e.g. other parameters.

elements.text: Maybe it could become an issue if in future releases the TimelineProvider implementation and system usage is changed? So when it is not the default
() anymore but with e.g. other parameters.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: I think getSnapshot and getTimeline would be the right place to do those - don't assume a guaranteed order between them though, you'd want to check in both methods. In general, avoid work specific to providing views in your `init`  and wait for those methods to be called instead. Your TimelineProvider may be created much more often then it's actually asked for views and entries.

<@U03JG18LGAG> asked
> [Follow-up]
> What is your recommended approach for CoreData migrations when CoreData is used in the main app and shared with the widget via app groups. Where would you recommend to handle the migration check? Because before each access to CoreData it has to be checked if a migration is available and if so, the migration has to be performed. In my understanding it can happen after an app update with a new CoreData model that the widget accesses CoreData before the app has been launched.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"[Follow-up]\nWhat is your recommended approach for CoreData migrations when CoreData is used in the main app and shared with the widget via app groups. Where would you recommend to handle the migration check? Because before each access to CoreData it has to be checked if a migration is available and if so, the migration has to be performed. In my understanding it can happen after an app update with a new CoreData model that the widget accesses CoreData before the app has been launched."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
You’re right that the extension could be called before the app is, after an app update.
So yes your CoreData layer would have to be prepared to migrate whether called from your extension or app
An alternative would be for the app to write out a simplified version of the data to JSON (say) for the widget extension to render from

messages.text:
<@U03JG18LGAG> asked
> Can Combine be used to handle the asynchronous tasks for getSnapshot or getTimeline? I am asking because Combine needs to store a reference to the AnyCancellable and I think this is not possible because the TimelineProvider struct is a value type (so it cannot have a mutable property).

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Can Combine be used to handle the asynchronous tasks for getSnapshot or getTimeline? I am asking because Combine needs to store a reference to the AnyCancellable and I think this is not possible because the TimelineProvider struct is a value type (so it cannot have a mutable property)."}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Even though your struct isn't mutable, you can create a class at init that it references. You can then mutate that and have it hold on to your AnyCancellable

elements.text: Even though your struct isn't mutable, you can create a class at init that it references. You can then mutate that and have it hold on to your AnyCancellable

slackdump_thread_replies.text: `IntentTimelineProvider` and `TimelineProvider` is a protocol, so you could have it implemented as a class instead of a struct.

elements.text: is a protocol, so you could have it implemented as a class instead of a struct.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Is it safe to implement the TimelineProvider as a class? I am wondering because in every sample code that I have seen it is always a struct.

elements.text: Is it safe to implement the TimelineProvider as a class? I am wondering because in every sample code that I have seen it is always a struct.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: If you do use a class, you should be careful about any state you set for sure.  The intent with the methods on the provider are to be stateless, so it matches better with a struct in that sense.

elements.text: If you do use a class, you should be careful about any state you set for sure.  The intent with the methods on the provider are to be stateless, so it matches better with a struct in that sense.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Maybe it does even make more sense to use a class then. Because if the same instance would call the getSnapshot or getTimeline again and the previous asynchronous combine call would not be finished yet, then it could be cancelled before starting a new one.

elements.text: Maybe it does even make more sense to use a class then. Because if the same instance would call the getSnapshot or getTimeline again and the previous asynchronous combine call would not be finished yet, then it could be cancelled before starting a new one.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Well do keep in mind the configurations of the Intent across calls could also be different, so keep that into consideration as well.

elements.text: Well do keep in mind the configurations of the Intent across calls could also be different, so keep that into consideration as well.

messages.text:
<@U03HMEM4TM5> asked
> For users with multiple widgets of the same app installed, can the app developer somehow do the work of reading widget data from disk once and use it to generate all timelines for all widgets at once?
> 
> Or maybe, could the widget extension be notified that it's about to start generating timelines and when it has ended, so we can prepare this info for all widget timeline generation within that time frame?
> 
> Thanks!

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You can certainly have a data model outside of your timeline providers that is shared between them, like a singleton. It can cache everything you need after the first load so that multiple widgets will benefit from whatever preparation it has done. After your widget content has been fetched, the extension is typically terminated, so there's no need to watch for a notification that it has ended to free up your resources

elements.text: You can certainly have a data model outside of your timeline providers that is shared between them, like a singleton. It can cache everything you need after the first load so that multiple widgets will benefit from whatever preparation it has done. After your widget content has been fetched, the extension is typically terminated, so there's no need to watch for a notification that it has ended to free up your resources

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Is it guaranteed to be terminated, though? I wouldn’t want to exhaust the widget budget

elements.text: Is it guaranteed to be terminated, though? I wouldn’t want to exhaust the widget budget

slackdump_thread_replies.text: (or worse, hold on to a SQlite database transaction that prevents the app from checkpointing)

elements.text: (or worse, hold on to a SQlite database transaction that prevents the app from checkpointing)

slackdump_thread_replies.text: It's not necessarily terminated, but the process is suspended shortly after the last timeline fetch occurs. I think your best bet is ensure your transaction has closed and flushed before calling completion on the timeline methods

elements.text: It's not necessarily terminated, but the process is suspended shortly after the last timeline fetch occurs. I think your best bet is ensure your transaction has closed and flushed before calling completion on the timeline methods

slackdump_thread_replies.text: The problem is, closing the transaction is the thing that is required to happen after all other readers are done. The transaction is what enforces consistent caches that can be reused across different widgets

elements.text: The problem is, closing the transaction is the thing that is required to happen after all other readers are done. The transaction is what enforces consistent caches that can be reused across different widgets

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Hm, I see. I'm not sure that I have enough context on SQLite to be very helpful. I'd suggest maybe reading all the data you need in to memory upfront and closing your transaction afterward, but that could also be costly depending on the amount of data.

elements.text: Hm, I see. I'm not sure that I have enough context on SQLite to be very helpful. I'd suggest maybe reading all the data you need in to memory upfront and closing your transaction afterward, but that could also be costly depending on the amount of data.

messages.text:
<@U03HVF46TEJ> asked
> Is there a maximum (or recommended max) size for a timeline, or is it more of a time limit for timeline generation? 
> 
> I have a widget I update every minute, so I could in theory make a timeline with thousands of entries. In practice, I am only able to *reliably* make a timeline with around 150-200 entries. Is that an actual limit somewhere? I know there’s a limit on how long we can take generating a timeline, but for a simple widget the difference between 200 entries and 500 is negligible. Maybe it’s memory? 
> 
> (Fun bonus complication: I have to limit my Mac widget to 100 entries because it seems to fail or “get stuck” way more often — does macOS actually have lower limits for widget timeline generation? Or maybe the process is way more throttled and thus more likely to time out?)

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Hi Christopher.  Yes, there are limits.  You should be able to have as many entries as you’d like, but be aware of the content that’s contained within them - if they each have unique and different images, you may find that the number of entries you can use are more limited.  Essentially it’s limited by the overall size of the final content that’s generated.

There are also time constraints on generating content that we place on widget authors.  The more entries you have (ie. 1000), the more likely you are to run into constraints against the time allotment of generating your timeline.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks. Is there a way to tell what limit(s) I'm hitting? In the debugger, remotely, anywhere?

<@U03J7BAGWFJ> Interesting. I am generating a few images using UIGraphics, but I am then caching them in-memory and reusing the same UIImage on subsequent entries. Would WidgetKit consider those "unique and different" images since it's not caching SwiftUI.Image or an Asset?

elements.text: Interesting. I am generating a few images using UIGraphics, but I am then caching them in-memory and reusing the same UIImage on subsequent entries. Would WidgetKit consider those "unique and different" images since it's not caching SwiftUI.Image or an Asset?

slackdump_thread_replies.text: We dedupe images where possible for efficiency.  There are scenarios where we do and where we don’t.  As long as you’re referencing the same image, I would expect things to behave as you’d expect.

elements.text: We dedupe images where possible for efficiency.  There are scenarios where we do and where we don’t.  As long as you’re referencing the same image, I would expect things to behave as you’d expect.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What's the advisable\/best-practice approach to passing data (immediately on call) from the main iOS app to home-screen or lock-screen widget, for immediate display\/reflection?\n\nWhat's the best way to access the same (large, added by folder reference rather than asset catalog) folder of images without \"Copy Bundle Resources\" in Xcode project Build Phases? It's added as a blue folder to main app, but paths to those images don't locate the image by the same NSBundle NSURL from Widget extension code.)"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: You should have your app & extension belong to the same App Group, at which point they can share a data container for file system access. Your app can write to disk (sqlite, json, …) and ask WidgetCenter to reload your widgets. The extension can read that data on disk to create the widget UI

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Please try to use opaque fill colors and text as much as possible! You can provide contrast between your own layers with varying greyscale values. Our own first party widgets were not updated to follow this guidance in time for seed 1, so don't follow their example.

We are actively investigating contrast and legibility issues. It's intended that any opaque color is legible. The system treatment to your content may change

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Thanks, good to know! So generally we should stick to Color.primary and .secondary for everything?

`Color.secondary` resolves to a transparent white at the moment; we're investigating if there could be some improvements to make this easier. The accessory Gauge, for example, uses .white for the dot and .black for the track.

> Widgets sometimes fail to update — they get “stuck” on an old value, they turn black, etc. Common non-crash causes (that I know of) include timeouts and using too much memory. What’s the best way to catch and log these problems? Are they logged as crashes or performance issues to App Store Connect? Are they on my device in the Console or logs?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Widgets sometimes fail to update \u2014 they get \u201cstuck\u201d on an old value, they turn black, etc. Common non-crash causes (that I know of) include timeouts and using too much memory. What\u2019s the best way to catch and log these problems? Are they logged as crashes or performance issues to App Store Connect? Are they on my device in the Console or logs?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
You should be able to tell in Console. If things are black it usually means a crash either on us on our end, or in the extension and we’re unable to read any views from it.
Be aware that images are newly restricted in size now – to about the same dimensions as your widget. Unlimited image sizes were causing issues before, so we’ve capped them.

<@U03HMCT187R> asked
> This question overlaps expertise with Core Data + CloudKit but do you have any general recommendations for implementing a widget that displays data that the app syncs? Eg, access it in a shared app group or write separate file to the app group from the app, and how to ensure it stays up-to-date? Thanks!

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"This question overlaps expertise with Core Data + CloudKit but do you have any general recommendations for implementing a widget that displays data that the app syncs? Eg, access it in a shared app group or write separate file to the app group from the app, and how to ensure it stays up-to-date? Thanks!"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Yes, if you’d like to share data between your widget extension and container application, you’ll want to do that via a shared app group container or use the network to pull the latest data for both.   Be careful if using the file system that if both processes (your extension and app) are running at the same time, accessing and/or mutating any shared cache data is safe for access.

elements.text: Yes, if you’d like to share data between your widget extension and container application, you’ll want to do that via a shared app group container or use the network to pull the latest data for both.   Be careful if using the file system that if both processes (your extension and app) are running at the same time, accessing and/or mutating any shared cache data is safe for access.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: SQLite is a reasonable option. It supports the scenario of one writer process (the app) and readers (the widget extension). With SQLite’s WAL I believe the single writer won’t block the reader at all.

elements.text: SQLite is a reasonable option. It supports the scenario of one writer process (the app) and readers (the widget extension). With SQLite’s WAL I believe the single writer won’t block the reader at all.

<@U03HZ4EJJ05> asked
> Sometimes widgets seem to get ‘stuck’. They no longer update but seem to show an old cached version. Do you know of any common reasons this may happen?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Sometimes widgets seem to get \u2018stuck\u2019. They no longer update but seem to show an old cached version. Do you know of any common reasons this may happen?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text: This can be a few things. Maybe your extension is crashing. But often it’s because you’re out of budget and have reached a reload limit for the day. This talks about budget: <https://developer.apple.com/documentation/widgetkit/keeping-a-widget-up-to-date> and also see WWDC’s 2021 WidgetKit talk

messages.text:
<@U03HMCT187R> asked
> Is WidgetCenter.shared.reloadTimelines rate limited on our behalf, or would triggering that 10x in 1 second (just an example lol) cause it to attempt getTimeline 10x? Do I need to be super careful about how often this can get called in a short amount of time (for example in response to database changes) or does it work similar to `UIView.setNeedsLayout` which will only result in one execution after a bit of a delay?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Is WidgetCenter.shared.reloadTimelines rate limited on our behalf, or would triggering that 10x in 1 second (just an example lol) cause it to attempt getTimeline 10x? Do I need to be super careful about how often this can get called in a short amount of time (for example in response to database changes) or does it work similar to `UIView.setNeedsLayout` which will only result in one execution after a bit of a delay?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
Yes, they can be rate limited and they may be coalesced by the system.  But depending upon your timing, you should also only call it when necessary.

If you flood the system with a bunch in a short duration, you may exhaust your allocated refresh budget quickly.  Sometimes you may want to do that, for example, if you were updating scores for a sports game.  However, other times you should probably be more exacting with it to ensure a good experience for your users.

I’d encourage coalescing as much as possible before sending a WidgetCenter.shared.reloadTimelines call - especially around a batch of database changes.

messages.text:
<@U03HVF46TEJ> asked
> Re: reloadTimelines budgeting, calling reload while my app is in the foreground doesn’t count against the budget, correct? So what counts as foreground? If I call reload in willResignActive is that foreground? What about calling it in didEnterBackground?

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"Re: reloadTimelines budgeting, calling reload while my app is in the foreground doesn\u2019t count against the budget, correct? So what counts as foreground? If I call reload in willResignActive is that foreground? What about calling it in didEnterBackground?"}]}

slackdump_thread_replies.text:
>> If I call reload in willResignActive is that foreground?
Yes.  Resign active is still considered foreground.

>> What about calling it in didEnterBackground?
This will still work as well as long as it’s not async’d.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"If I call reload in willResignActive is that foreground?"}],"border":1}

elements.text: Yes.  Resign active is still considered foreground.

elements.Raw: {"type":"rich_text_quote","elements":[{"type":"text","text":"What about calling it in didEnterBackground?"}],"border":1}

elements.text: This will still work as well as long as it’s not async’d.

slackdump_thread_replies.text: Awesome thanks!
And yes, refreshes while foreground are considered “free” from a budgeting perspective.

elements.text: And yes, refreshes while foreground are considered “free” from a budgeting perspective.
